seg.output:
Grace and peace from the Lord.
I received your letters along with those you mention in them, and I was delighted beyond measure as before.But I fear that those you sent to Franfordia will not arrive to me so easily, since there is no one to deliver my letters and to bring back yours as I had arranged.For the one I had hired in the meantime, unexpectedly left earlier due to the wedding of his sister in his homeland.They say that he usually attends the fairs with individual books for sale, and stays in the same hostel with the people of Zurich, if what I have been told is true.In the future, if God allows, it will be handled better.
I sent you letters in the month of August last, along with a citizen of Cologne, who faithfully received them to deliver to your hands, in which I asked that your annotations on the Second Letter of John should be sent along.For I had entrusted the former ones to a certain brother, who does not return them and they are not yet in Cologne as recently.Otherwise I would not burden you in this regard.I eagerly await your commentaries on the Letter to the Hebrews along with your dearest writings, and if I do not receive them, as I hope, I will blame no one but myself.
I congratulate you on the success and peace of your church and I ask that the same could be written of us sometime.For those who favor the gospel and the glory of Christ must remain silent with us, since, as you know, we are surrounded everywhere by Pharisaic regulations.I judge that the unlearned people should be forgiven, who wish to serve God with all their might and think that what they do - for nothing else is taught - is pleasing to God alone.Therefore, nothing would please me more than the pure preaching of the gospel at the beginning.

I congratulate you sincerely on the success and peace of your church and I pray that the same could be said of us one day. For we who are in favor of the gospel and the glory of Christ must make our voices heard. As you know, we are surrounded by pharisaic constitutions. I must forgive the people in my judgment, who wish to serve God with all their efforts and who believe that what they do - since nothing else is taught - pleases God alone. Nothing, then, would I prefer at the beginning than for the gospel to be accepted purely. Then, without a doubt, all other abuses will gradually decay and pass away. seg.output: Grace and peace from the Lord. I was delighted beyond measure when I received your letter along with those whose mention you made in it, as I had been previously. I fear, however, that the things you have sent to Franford will not reach me as easily, since there is no one to deliver my letters and reclaim yours as we had agreed. The one I had employed for this purpose unexpectedly left earlier due to a wedding in his homeland. It is said that he usually attends the markets with his books for sale and lodges with the people of Zurich. In the past month of August, I gave letters to a man from Cologne, who faithfully promised to deliver them to you; I asked him to send your notes on the Second Epistle of John. I had entrusted the earlier letters to a certain friend, who has not returned them, nor do they appear to be in Cologne as recently. Otherwise, I would have not burdened you with this. I anxiously await your dear writings and the commentaries on the Epistle to the Hebrews, and if I do not receive them, as I hope, I will only blame myself. I congratulate you for your success and the peace of your church, and I wish the same could be said of us. We, who are favourable to the gospel and the glory of Christ, must remain silent in the face of Pharisaic constitutions, as you know. I consider it to be necessary to forgive the rude people of my judgement, who desire to serve God with utmost effort and believe that what they do - since they are not taught otherwise - pleases God. Nothing, therefore, would be more desirable in the beginning than the pure acceptance of the gospel.
